title: Represent SHM - vertical spring - h-vs-t graph

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows a block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> hanging from a spring and oscillating in the vertical direction. Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a graph of the block’s height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> above the floor as a function of time <math alttext="lowercase t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. The block oscillates with a period <math alttext="uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math> in the range <math alttext="0.8 h sub max, less than or equal to h, less than or equal to h sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.8</mn><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> during its motion, where <math alttext="h sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> is the maximum height reached by the block. The dots in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> represent the block at three different times: <math alttext="lowercase t equals, one half times uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase t equals, three fourths times uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi></math>, and <math alttext="lowercase t equals uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>T</mi></math>.(a) In Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, indicate the block’s acceleration at each time shown as follows.If the acceleration is zero at any time(s), write “<math alttext="a, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” just below the corresponding dot(s).If the acceleration is nonzero at any time(s), indicate the direction of the acceleration by drawing an arrow that starts on, and points away from, the corresponding dot(s).

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows a block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> hanging from a spring and oscillating in the vertical direction. Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a graph of the block’s height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> above the floor as a function of time <math alttext="lowercase t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. The block oscillates with a period <math alttext="uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math> in the range <math alttext="0.8 h sub max, less than or equal to h, less than or equal to h sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.8</mn><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> during its motion, where <math alttext="h sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> is the maximum height reached by the block. The dots in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> represent the block at three different times: <math alttext="lowercase t equals, one half times uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase t equals, three fourths times uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi></math>, and <math alttext="lowercase t equals uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>T</mi></math>.(a) In Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, indicate the block’s acceleration at each time shown as follows.If the acceleration is zero at any time(s), write “<math alttext="a, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” just below the corresponding dot(s).If the acceleration is nonzero at any time(s), indicate the direction of the acceleration by drawing an arrow that starts on, and points away from, the corresponding dot(s).

Consider the time range <math alttext="one half uppercase T, less than or equal to lowercase t, less than or equal to uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>T</mi></math>.(b) Starting with either the work-energy theorem or the relation <math alttext="W equals, F sub parallel, end sub, d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mo>∥</mo></msub><mi>d</mi></math>, derive expressions for the following quantities in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="h sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing either a fundamental physics principal or an equation from the reference book.<math alttext="W sub g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mtext>g</mtext></msub></math>, the work done on the block by gravitational forces during the indicated time range.<math alttext="W sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math>, the net work done on the block by all forces during the indicated time range.<math alttext="W sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mtext>s</mtext></msub></math>, the work done on the block by the spring during the indicated time range.

(c) Consider the time range <math alttext="0 less than or equal to lowercase t, less than or equal to one half uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>T</mi></math>, and take the upward direction to be positive.i. On Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the block’s velocity <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> as a function of the block’s height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> above the floor.
ii. On Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the block’s acceleration as a function of the block’s height above the floor.

(d) Indicate whether either one of the graphs you drew in part (c) is consistent or not consistent with the expression for <math alttext="W sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>W</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> you derived in part (b), and justify your answer.Note: You only need to analyze one of the graphs from part (c).

skill.text: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.
